title: 'Outsider' Emma Watson says she felt worthless at school because she 'didn't fit in'
text:

Harry Potter star Emma Watson has revealed she felt worthless at school because she didn’t fit in. 
The British actress, 26, famed for playing wizard sidekick Hermione Granger in JK Rowling’s movie franchise, has spoken of the peer pressure she endured at a young age - but has told youngsters going through a tough time, “don’t give up”. 
Emma, who stars in Disney’s Beauty And the Beast as heroine Belle, admits: “I remember feeling at school that if I didn’t fit there was nothing else. And that’s a really difficult feeling.” 
Emma, who found fame when she was just 11 and is now worth an estimated £57million, was privately educated in Oxford between filming the eight Harry Potter movies. 
And she urges those who feel left out at school to pursue their passions and find their tribes. Read More How to get FREE cinema tickets to see Beauty and the Beast at Cineworld this weekend Emma, pictured with Rupert Grint and Daniel Radcliffe, was educated privately during the Harry Potter years (Photo: PA) 
She says: “I would say for anyone that feels like an outsider in their environment, there is a big, wide world out there with so many different people with diverse opinions and perspectives and interests, and go out there and find your tribe, go find your kindred spirits, and they do exist, they don’t necessarily come easily. 
“Pursue the things that you love and that you’re really passionate about. They’ll be there. But don’t give up. They are there.” 
It comes as the actress took legal action this week after photographs of her were stolen. The pictures show her trying on outfits during a fitting. But her spokesman, who could give no details on who stole the images, made it clear they did not show the actress nude. 
Earlier this month Emma was criticised for posing topless in a shoot for Vanity Fair magazine. Emma stars as Belle in the Beauty And The Beast live action remake (Photo: SCU) 
Images of the actress wearing a bolero jacket with nothing underneath triggered a backlash as she was accused of being hypocritical, given her strong feminist stance. 
She has even given Belle a feminist makeover, explaining: “I love that in our version Belle is not only kind of awed and doesn’t fit in, and you know, you see her reading, and you see her not really a part of the community. 
“In our film she’s actually an activist within her own community. She’s teaching other young girls who are part of the village to read, and you know, moments like that where you could see her expanding beyond just her own little world and trying to kind of grow it, I loved that, and yeah, that was amazing to get to do.” 
Emma says the character was an inspiration to her even from a very young age. Read More Amanda Seyfried's nude photos reportedly HACKED including 'intimate moments' with her ex-boyfriend after Emma Watson leak Downton's Dan Stevens plays Beast (Photo: PUBLICITY PIX) 
She said: “It’s really remarkable to play someone that I’m almost sure had an influence on the woman that I have become.” 
Emma starred opposite Downton Abbey hunk Dan Stevens, 34, who played the Beast. She added: “I just called him Beastie. Hi Beastie.” Like us on Facebook
